reviewText: Sex and the City - Season Six, Part 2 is an emotional and heartwarming conclusion to this absolutely wonderful show. So glad the movie version will be out in May but until then we can watch these great episodes again and again. Sarah Jessica Parker and Cynthia Nixon won much deserved Emmy's that year. Kim Cattrall and Kristin Davis also sparkle the last season as well, Samantha is diagnosed with breast cancer and falls in love with Smith, while Charlotte becomes a mother to a King Charles Springer Spaniel and a baby from China. Chris Noth returns as Big to finally win Carrie back and we learn Big's first name! and Miranda marries Steve and they purchase a house in Brooklyn. Hard to find a show where all six seasons are brilliant and never jumped the shark. I highly recommend this gem!
summary: "You are living in a fantasy..."

reviewText: I am a SATC fan, and have seen each season several times. Luckily, I had the Season 6 Part 2 on Demand on cable and have seen each episode at least 5 times.Out of all the seasons, Season 6 is my favorite. Season 5 was a bit dark and introspective for all of the girls but in Season 6 things start to come together. Part 2 is filled with nostalgia as it seems the producers knew that the series was coming to an end and wanted to imbue it with the best they had yet. The Part 2 introduces a new man in Carrie's life after Berger leaves - Petrovsky who is a Russian artist. For those of you who may not have seen it earlier I don't want to give spoilers but Samantha, Miranda and Charlotte all seem to have come of age in this season and seem relatively well settled in their lives.The last 2 episodes are my very favorite, as they bring together all of the characters in a very nostalgic fashion and I must admit some scenes in the very last episode had me wiping a tear...the music score was absolutely wonderful complementing the setting. In this part all of the women seem not only more in touch with their inner self but also reach out to care for those around them.If you are a SATC fan, then this part is a must buy!
summary: The best Season of Sex and the City - romantic and funny!

Title: N/A

reviewText: I liked this run of eight episodes that lead up to the finale and conclusion of SEX AND THE CITY.  They hit all the right notes with each of the girls.  Carrie lives a fantasy and questions her own reality, Charlotte yearns for a family with Harry, Miranda has to come to terms with her love for Steve, and Samantha finally realizes she needs someone who adores her.  It's beautifully written, well photographed, and moving.  Oh yeah, and it's also funny as hell owing a lot to 1930s screwball comedy.This set includes 4 commentaries by Michael Patrick King, the two HBO tributes, a discussion with the writers and Sarah Jessica Parker, three alternate endings (really just three takes of a coffee shop scene), and deleted scenes from all six seasons.  I hate they split season two into two halves, but at least this set has nicer extras than any of the other sets.  And it's the end which (despite being a guy)I can never sit through without tearing up.  Sunday nights will never be the same!
summary: Classy end to the search for SEX

reviewText: Sex and the City is a fabulous show and this is one of the better seasons. I've watched these DVDs over and over, and while the episodes are always entertaining, the packaging leaves a little to be desired.The plastic case that all the DVDs come in starts to fall apart at the edges after opening it up several times. And there's no episode guide inside, so if you're looking for a particular episode, you'll have to put each DVD in your player to look for it, or search the web.I still recommend buying it though, because it's one of those DVD sets you'll watch over and over again. I feel like I got my money's worth, even if my cases do need some tape to stay together.
summary: Great Show, but the Packaging Needs Work

reviewText: I own the other SATC collections, so I'm not about to leave my collection unfinished.  Particularly with the BEST episode of the entire series ever (beating My Motherboard, Myself from season 4, which, believe me, was no small feat in the excellent series), in American Girl in Paris Part Deux.  That episode alone makes this a worthwhile purchase.The Series wrapped up with many nice surprises.  Charlotte's new passion was not only fitting, but really suited the 'new' Charlotte.  Miranda's acceptance of the consequences of her new life were masterfully played by Cynthia Nixon.  Catrall...Dear LORD how talented is this woman?  Her protrayal of Samantha in the most serious stages of her illness was classic Samantha, but with a vulnerability never seen in this character. (Particularly the Samantha/Smith relationship and it's very natural development.)  And, of course, SJP wraps up the chapter of Carries life in a very acceptable fashion.The series' end was handled wonderfully and respectably for all involved (no miracle pregnancy for charlotte, no Carrie's Wedding).  This is fine television at it's best, and any series fan will have to own this, just on principle alone.That being said, I agree with the earlier review who said HBO isn't real 'user friendly' when it comes to programming their DVD's.  I'd like to be able to watch one episode after another, but ya gotta keep running back and forth between menus.  And, as I said in this episode's predecessor review...Why only half a season?  What????  But, now that you have both parts, it makes it a whole.  A pricey whole in relation to the other, full-season-in-one-package wholes, but at least complete.Now, one gripe I have moreso with this portion of the series was Mikhail Barishnikov's character.  I could never warm up to him, and aside from providing some kinda father figure 'thing', I couldn't see why in the world Carrie would have ever been attracted to him, much less moved to Paris with him!  That was the only part I found slightly 'off' in an otherwise perfect season.But, the best twenty minutes of writing happen in the last section of the last episode, and I cannot fathom how any fan of this series or these characters doesn't require at least 5 hankies to make it through.  It's a wonderful end to a wonderful series.
summary: A fine end for a terrific series, but again with the half?
Title: N/A

reviewText: This final installment of the series is superb.  My only complaint is that it is too short!  I just want this show to keep going!Once again, the show deals with those difficult female dilemmas: marriage, babies, happiness, and being alone (rather than being lonely) in a modern, feminist city (or are we already post-feminist?).  But we also watch them tackle romance, balance, and serious health issues.In perfect SATC style, each issue is presented with respect and kindness, served up with honesty, and a healthy dose of laughter.  Each woman has her own demons to struggle with, including each other.But the series ends well, and in my opinion perfectly.  Everyone is where she should be!(As for the extras, I watched them once, and will probably never see them again.)
summary: What an Ending!!

reviewText: As, I do not have HBO,I rushed to get this 3 disc DVD the first day it came out. I then sat all day and watched all three discs. The last 2 episodes were the best of the the 8 episodes and I admit I cried at the last scenes.Plus the shots of Paris are just beautiful. The shot where Carrie is running and the Eiffel Tower shimmering in the backround is just breathtaking. Plus the music choices in the last episode are great, the final song combined with the scene gave me gooseumps. I couldn't have asked for a better way to end a fabulous series and I'm very happy with the end results. The only thing that would have made this DVD better was if they had included more extras, such as more cut scenes and more bloopers. Plus I would have loved some commentary with the four girls on the last episode. The different endings were not what I expected and weren't even considered as endings, they were just something to throw off the press. But still a must for all Sex fans. A great end to a series- "well, that's just fabulous".
summary: Last season of a great series

reviewText: Endings are hard for sit-coms.  The characters on even the most sophisticated shows change very little.  At it best, the genre mines wrinkles in a character that add depth, but do not change the basic persona."Sex & the City" was one of the greatest TV comedies of all time.  However, it faced many of the same problems that faced other great TV comedies ending their run. It had four interesting characters that were original, but had become comic archtypes over the run of the series.  It also had an audience in seeing those characters get a '... happily ever after' moment that did not betray everything that had come before.The focus on relationships as a source of comedy gave the series something to work with entering its final season that many comedies did not have.  However, the series resolved its characters with very mixed results.  From worst to best:4.  Charlotte - The writers decided that her value system was in need of changing.  As a result, she is paired with a near opposite in Harry.  To make this match, the prim and Waspy Charlotte is forced to leave most of what she values behind.3. Carrie - Is presented with a false choice between an under-developed Russian and her central, series-long romantic interest of Mr. Big.  Gee ... I wonder who she chose?  Also, tons of over the top set-up dialouge.2.  Samantha - The cancer is handled far better than you might have feared.  Also, she resolves her relationship in a manner consistent with her character.1.  Mirannda - This character actually evolved over the course of the show.  The tiny changes add up to a big pay-off in the final episode.
summary: Tepid Ending for a Great Show

reviewText: Director/EP M. P. King  invests significant efforts to flesh out the sublime and surprising aspects of this series that would have gone almost unnoticed otherwise... what a treasured treat knowing I had a tour guide not only of the NYC backdrop but the character development, POV, and heart of the ensemble...  I also have had a lifetime crush on Michail and found his presence mesmerizing and comments to the effect of "I can't believe I am shooting a scene with the Great Misha" was most appreciated...  falling in love with someone so out of your league is full of unearthly excitement and elevates one's existence if only for a fleeting New York minute, how easily we forget this occurs so infrequently and a genuine gift of life that was translated extremely well with this additional expert insight..... King's contribution truly stands out when compared with so many others and transcends the typical bland 'block, light, and schedule' challenges... he knows his audience intimately and extended a phenomenal ability to smell every rose en vie!!!  kudos
summary: Michael Patrick King Commentary Exemplary!!!! 10+

reviewText: SATC's last eight episodes differ markedly from the earlier shows of the series and we get a healthy sense of closure. The "girls" have matured. Each builds on her strengths -- the preppy Charlotte, sexy Samantha and brainy Miranda -- to find long-term relationships with terrific, supportive men.Except (so far) Carrie!  Ironically, Carrie attracts strong sophisticated men, while retaining a rather naive, unsophisticated perspective.  Although her character is fun to watch, she doesn't gain confidence and she's culturally narrow.  Whether with Big or "The Russian," she's outclassed.The arc of Carrie's story could be a case study in life transition. As a career consultant, I've met people who, like Carrie, make momentous decisions in the name of love, family and relationships.  Often they're fearful of being alone (like Carrie) or they feel they owe someone a major sacrifice.As Carrie soon learns, moving changes the dynamics of a relationship -- especially if earning patterns change too. And once on his own turf, her lover becomes less attentive and even less sensitive than he was in New York.  I've known many people who divorced soon after a life-changing move. She also sees a rather mean side of him: he's manipulative. When she starts to make her own friends in Paris, his "anxiety attack" keeps her close by. He seems to view girlfriends as objects to purchase and enjoy for awhile. That's fine for the right girl but not Carrie.Like many highly successful people, Carrie viewed her world as either-or. Either stay in New York or move to Paris. She could have insisted on a trial period in Paris, without giving up her job.  Or she could have done a lot more research. And her situation was extremely precarious: Alexander didn't invite marriage, and they didn't seem to have any sort of legal contract (which would be tricky to enforce internationally, anyway). So she could be left high and dry after five or ten years, forced to start over, with Alexander owing her nothing.  And at 38, there's more than a biological clock ticking: there's a work clock, too.  Job are a lot harder to get at 45 than 35.The ending left me satisfied because the next chapter in these women's lives would call for a totally different kind of show. Miranda's buried in family responsibilities; Samantha's settling down with her almost-too-good-to-be-true lover; Charlotte's got dogs and, eventually motherhood.  A sitcom about play dates and family may be fun -- but different.  The upbeat New York energy of this show would have to change.The writers should be congratulated for taking on tough issues while keeping us entertained.
summary: From independent professional to trailing spouse
Title: N/A

reviewText: I usually dislike happy endings because they usually just don't feel REAL but simply contrived, manipulative, and cliche.Well, the season finale of SATC was a bit too HAPPY/rose-tinted for my tastes but, hee hee, I have to confess to mostly enjoying it despite the sometimes way too heavy-handed symbolism (Carrie with her necklaces, especially).Chris Noth ("Mr. Big") as always, steals the show.  This man has incredible screen presence/charisma and really ought to be in more projects.David Eigenberg ("Steve") finally is given a chance to show off other sides of his character in the season finale, and we see that he truly is an accomplished actor, not just a very "aw shucks" impossible-not-to-like down-home Brooklyn boy.Mikhail Baryshnikov puts in a solid performance as he has in all of his episodes, but his character does not change much.The only weak moments was Carrie's breakup speech towards the end of the finale, which seemed way too written and overextended her finite acting abilities.About the only thing I will not miss from this show is seeing some of Carrie's fashion disasters...she dresses beautifully half of the time, and the other half of the time just makes you wonder, "What in the hell is she thinking???"  But that's a truly minor complaint, for a smart, witty, often hilarious and poignant show that has very very few peers in today's TV desert.
summary: Surprisingly good for a bunch of happy endings...!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Although I thought the episodes included in this DVD were all fantastic, I have to say I was a bit disappointed with the bonus features. When I first heard of the three alternate endings along with deleted scenes for all the episodes, I thought- Awesome! After watching these bonus features, I found them to be a bit of a let down. The alternate endings all seemed to be more like deleted scenes rather than alt. endings. They didn't seem to have much thought put into them, at least not as much as I expected. All 3 endings were all just different dialogue in that last scene in the coffee shop. The outcome of Carrie's life were very different in each scene but it was like they came up with the ending at the last second for fun. They didnt even bother to explain how they got to that point. I would have been more satisfied with that if there was an audio commentary included with the deleted scenes and "alt. endings" but there were none. This is the last DVD of the whole season. I didn't think it was too much to ask, as an avid Sex fan, to make this one awesome and worth the 35-40 bucks they charge for it. I feel like they just kind of threw the material together with a commentary here and there for some choice episodes, threw some "bonus features" together which I found to be so half-assed, and charge top dollar for it even though it only had 8 episodes. I gave this DVD 3 stars because I was so psyched to finally complete my collection of all Sex seasons and I think the show is brilliant. I just felt a bit disappointed with what you get for your money...Not much.
summary: A bit of a let-down for Sex fans
Title: N/A

reviewText: It ended just how I wanted it to end.  And as delusionary as it may seem, it probably gives hope to many women that their man will eventually come around and realize their worth, and grow to love them.  The inner romantic within me responded with a resounding "yes".Carrie's ending was romantic, just as she deserved.  One interesting thing I noted was that in Season 6 for the first time, Carrie didn't act neurotic and crazy for a relationship.  She seemed so much more mature, even though Mikhail acted the spoiled brat.  It felt good to see her progress and grow.  As for Miranda, the life she ended up with felt wholesome and complete for me, like she learned what was truly important for her own life.  The part with Steve's mom losing her mind was so beautifully done, you couldn't help but empathize with her.I know that introducing a cancer storyline can seem forced and campy, but the way they did it in SITC seemed pretty good.  It didn't overwhelm the other storylines, which is something I appreciated.All in all, a great finish to a great show.  I know alot of people are upset at the price and it being split into two seasons, but it costs alot of money to make these shows.  Their profits will go toward producing more quality shows, and I will gladly pay more money for HBO to do this.  As for people calling the producers "greedy", I'm sure those same people would sell their grandmother's teeth if they needed some spare cash.One more thing:  The extras on this set aren't really that great, especially the three endings.  if you're going to buy it, it's going to be for the episodes themselves.  They stand alone, as far as I'm concerned and they don't require extras.
summary: Best ending.  I DON'T MIND the price.

reviewText: Part 1 of Season 6 was tasteful without being contrived for a no-holds barred series featuring the occasional spattering of foul language.  All the essential ingredients that made Part 1 good watching (great lines, decent character development and pacing) was sadly absent in Part 2. The supporting cast's roles were even more diminished and their storylines more farcical or hastily skimmed through. The serious chapter and verses that led to Sarah Jessica Parker's grand finale in Paris turned out to be nothing but a drag.  The "happy" ending for Carrie and big was so formulaic and uninspiring. The haute couture was probably the only saving grace to Part 2. If you have access to the Zone 3, two parts-in-one edition, get it instead (priced US$40, sans Special Features, but who cares for the over-rated alternative endings from the over-priced (US$57.48) Zone 1, Part 1 & 2 edition)?!
summary: Part 2 of Season 6 - Major Anti-Climax

reviewText: Through out Sex and the City, Carrie has been the most indecisive, and sometimes stubborn character.  Her ups and downs sometimes seem to be so insignficant.  But then again isn't every women's life like that.  Surely we dont' run around NYC with a pair of Manolo's but the truth is we all see ourselves in Carrie, Miranda, Samantha or Charlotte.  And sometimes we wish we were like the characters, a femme fatale, a truly optimistic Charlotte who is so good to the core, a pessimist like Miranda, or a Carrie.  This final season was a closing anthem to these four magnificent women.  Four women who all women want to be like.  Carrie's finally year in Sex and the City was a clsoing title.  All four girls closed the books on their single lives as they knew it.  It was good to know that they were all ok, but is there really room for a movie or renuion?  The question that has been plaguing everyone since the end of the 5th season?  I question the ability to bring back the magic of the show, and to really have a strong story line... would it be another wedding? we saw 3 already that were of the girls.  We could never imagine Samantha marrying, and Carrie? We would have to fly in the most outrageous designers for this... It wouldn't be vera wang.. it would be someone beyond the scope of my simple mind.  But this is it ladies, the last season, and the most memorable one... Enjoy!
summary: A significant event in Carrie's career

reviewText: Not having had HBO during the last two seasons of this, one of our favorite shows ever, deprived us from learning about the resolution of the lives of these four crazy Manhattanites we all learned to love and follow. So, as soon as it came out in late 2004, we checked part two of the sixth and last season. We were not dissapointed.Strong production values and solid writing go hand in hand with some of the best acting they've delivered throughout the series. Without taking away from the other six episodes included in this set, in particular the last two episodes, shot on location in Paris, show how the producers were not willing to ruin the fantastic work of the past six years.How are we left? With a mixed flavor of nostalgia and satisfaction. The same feeling you have when you know something is over, but it was something very good, very special. Carrie, Miranda, Charlotte and Samantha will indeed be missed... or perhaps they became immortal and an indelible part of contemporary pop culture.
summary: Sex and the City will be missed

reviewText: Season Six did a wonderful job in closing the arcs of the 4 New York women, but not tying everything up into a neat little package with a bow on top.  It could be the end of one series, or the start of a new series.One theory I had throughout watching the show (which I did not watch on HBO during its run, but started watching via DVD after the show ended its run), was that none of the women other than Carrie actually existed, that they were all various aspects of a whole personality. A viewer often wonders how the women could have ever met or become friends without a catalyst.  For example, when or where would Samantha and Charlotte have met without completely hating each other at first sight? One Amazon reviewer said, rightly, that Carrie seemed to be always outclassed by her men, Big and Russian in particular.  But when you combine all the women into a whole person, you get someone who would be a match for anyone or anything, including the City of New York.  Yes, it's rather Freudian, with Samantha playing the Id, Charlotte the Ego, and Miranda the Super-ego.  Or maybe Jungian, with each woman being an archetype - Carrie being the child who needs the other 3 archetypes to become a fully realized adult.  S&TC; never resorted to such gimmicks, but Season Six carries enough symbology that such a theory is possible without ever being overt.All the characters were so delightful, from the primaries to the cameos. The 4 women all have to make difficult choices, and must give up something in order to gain something so much better.  Their men - Big, Steve, Harry, and Smith - all become the men we wish we knew and loved.  And their lives have all becomed entwined with ours.
summary: The End (or The Beginning)
Title: N/A

reviewText: It's finally here!  I'm very happy that Season 6, Part 2 was finally released on DVD.  I was a bit miffed at first that HBO decided to be greedy and release the final season of "Sex and the City" in two parts just to make a bigger profit, but I'm not all that angry anymore.  The episodes included in this DVD set are some of the best of the entire series.  I could watch the final episode a thousand times without ever getting tired of it.My biggest gripe with this DVD set is that the three alternate endings for the series finale leave a lot to be desired.  There was so much hype leading up to the series finale about how three completely different endings were filmed, and I was expecting to see those different endings on the DVD set.  However, the different endings on the DVD are basically just three slight variations of the same exact scene.  I was hoping to see a scene where Carrie tells Big to kiss off, the Russian proposes marriage, etc., but we don't get any of that.  Everything is just alluded to.Despite the lame alternate endings, this is a great DVD set.  Fans will especially enjoy the short montage of deleted scenes from all six seasons as well as the show retrospectives/documentaries.
summary: Fabulous in spite of some small disappointments

reviewText: I can't think of anything more boring than having to sit and watch four barely dressed women in expensive shoes running all over New York to have sex with anything that moves.  What has our society come to?  Are we that starved for entertainment?  Why would you want to purchase a dvd like this when  all you have to do is look out of your window and see the same thing, especially if you live in NY?  Walk through Central Park or ride the subways.  It's all there for free!!!  Wake up folks!  There's real entertainment out there, I promise.
summary: Is this what they call entertainment?

reviewText: I bought all seasons for my daughter.  This series was revolutionary for it's time.  Very sexy and funny.  My daughter is an urbanite trapped in suburbia.  She enjoyed them.  I would recommend all seasons in this series.  PS, don't buy or watch the movies made after the series was complete.  They were horrible.  Not even a shadow as good as the television series.  Recommended, but sadly, becoming a little outdated already!  Note of caution, not for the easily offended, some of the humor "more cable" than "primetime TV" if you know what I mean.
summary: Television series was good

reviewText: This 3-disc set contains the final episodes of the TV serial: Sex and the City.  Each episode showed originally on TV, but each episode here is greatly expanded in length and depth as compared to the TV versions.  First, there is a lot more sex, with the requisite nudity, often by Samantha.  Second, there is more emotion; we see emotions frayed to levels not seen in any of the TV serials.  An example is the argument between Miranda and Carrie before Carrie heads of to Paris.  Third, the relationships are more fleshed out, and we get a better explanation of why certain individuals act the way they do.  The plot lines stay the same though, and so do all the endings.  Even the TV show ends the same way as it started, with Carrie and Mr. Big together.  The special features are nothing much to speak of, except for interviews with all the actors and actresses.  Overall, the five hours or so of the show are fairly comical and quite enjoyable.
summary: The end

reviewText: A lot of my friends didnt like the whole russian thing, but I like it..i thought he was very complex and sort of hot, I got what Carrie saw in him..frankly, I could never quite understand what Carrie saw in Big, I mean he treated her poorly, he made fun of all of her boyfriends in the most immature way, he cheated on his wife with her, he left for California when she needed him most, I was not surprised how the show ended..but does anybody believe that that would last?...COME ON!!..I liked the Miranda story line, it was touching and i was glad she was happy at last..as for Charlotte, well, she got her Park Avenue apt. and a guy that made lots of money, so I guess she was happy, as shallow and sad as that is...as for Samantha, she got the hottest man I have ever seen, so she ended up on top..as always..this is a good ending for the series, but I liked the first half of season six better than the last half, not that this was not very good..but the first half of season six, is a classic...oh and frankly, dont bother over paying for this ..just do like we all do and buy the box set..it's so worth it..
summary: HOW  WILL NEW YORK SURVIVE WITHOUT THESE WOMEN

reviewText: After six seasons on the air and 94 episodes filmed "Sex and the City" came to its conclusion in 2004. There will never be another series like it on television. Like the "Golden Girls" in the eighties and nineties, "Sex and the City" dealt with the issue of female friendship and how those relationships are important when people are going through life's troubles, and the fact that no matter what life throws your way, as long as you have friends you will overcome everyday obstacles.In this box set that features the last ten shows Carrie starts to date a Russian artist named Petrovsky, who sweeps her off her feet and off to Paris near the end of the season; Charlotte marries Harry, but discovers she has miscarried. The two then adopt a beautiful dog named Elizabeth Taylor when Charlotte discovers she can never carry children full term; Miranda marries Steve and moves to Brooklyn with Brady where she cares for Steve's sick mother; and perhaps most touching this season Samantha discovers she has breast cancer and is fearful Smith will leave her.The final episode entitled "An American Girl in Paris, Part Deux" was the highest rated episode in the series' run bringing in over ten million viewers, making "Sex and the City"s finale one of the highest rated in televison history.
summary: "Here's The End Of A Classic Series"
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm referring to the bonus materials on Season 6, Part 2, which includes two superficial tributes to the creator, writers, cast and crew of SATC. Someone (Darren Star, maybe?) says that NYC is "the fifth lady". Elsewhere in the same tribute, is a clip of Carrie saying she's been on a date with NYC for 18 years, "and it's getting serious." Ah, it was the Fleet Week episode. As she walks away from the visiting Louisiana sailor who really didn't care for NYC, she says, in a voiceover, "I can't have *no one* [sic] talking s--t about my boyfriend."I must say, in the tributes, Sarah Jessica Parker looks far more beautiful than Carrie did in all six seasons.I took a star off because of the too-frequent commentary by the insufferable Kathy Griffin (and really, once would have been too much). Really, what was she doing there? Or, for that matter, Ivanka Trump or Heidi Klum?If you were a series fan, this is obviously something you want to buy. People say different things about the finale, but I thought it was just perfect, extremely emotionally satisfying.One of the commentators I did enjoy was series semi-regular Mario ("Anthony") Cantone, who made short work of women who come up to him and say "I'M CARRIE!!!" His comeback isn't repeatable here, but I wish he'd repeat it to certain posters on the SATC board at imdb.com.The entire series is a blast. It's even better when you have the luxury of watching it on DVD.And Stanford Blatch is still adorable.
summary: OK, is NYC the "Fifth Lady" OR is it Carrie's boyfriend??

reviewText: There is nothing that I don't love about this DVD set. I can't help wishing that the seasons could just go on and on forever. Carrie, Samantha, Miranda, and Charlote are such great friends that you want to be there with them at the coffee shop hanging out. From the first episode to the very last, I was glued to HBO, waiting for what happened next. With my DVD collection, I am able to go back and visit again and again.
summary: LOVED IT

reviewText: Like many, I will miss SATC, it was a truly special series.  Rewatching season 1 the other night reaffirmed the appeal of this show.  THe great characters, the ridiculous scenarios they were involved in, and the great comedy. Even if Series 5 onwards was a bit flat, but still managed to make me laugh.  I will miss the girls.In America, Season 6 is split for its DVD release.  The first half is available now, while the remainder is not due until after christmas. The Australian and UK DVD release contain the full series, except they miss out on the great special features that the impending American DVD (ie. second half of Season 6) will have.True fans will want it all ...
summary: International DVD of Series 6
Title: N/A

reviewText: Okay, I loved SATC up until the end. At the very end, the magical moment, the very happy closure, all 4 of them end up in relatively serious relationships with men. I am disappointed. Why can't one of them just be by herself and happy? Do we really need any more pressure to co-exist? So, I am left with the 1938 classic Gone With The Wind to reassure myself that single women can still be happy and look forward to tomorrow (Never mind that Scarlett is already plotting to get Rhett back.) Anyway, it was entertaining along the way but I truly wish it had less of a Hollywood symmetrical ending. Oh well, you can't always get what you want... but this was certainly what I needed along the way so I give it 3 stars.
summary: Everyone ends up with a male figure, give me a break!
